abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Refinery Engineering
            and Energy Efficiency Project for Pakistan was satisfactory.
            The project achieved its main objectives, its impact has
            been substantial, sustainability is more than likely, and
            both the Bank and Borrower acted satisfactorily. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, the project
            experience highlights the potential risk of undertaking
            projects for the secondary upgrading of refined products in
            developing countries, which lack a rational ex-refinery
            pricing policy. The absence of such a policy makes it
            difficult to determine the economic viability of secondary
            upgrading projects. Second, the slippage in disbursing only
            37.5 percent of the original loan amount emphasizes the need
            to establish a more realistic project schedule and to be
            more cognizant of potential technical problems and schedule
            delays during the early stages of a project. Third, the Bank
            should be more prompt in responding to Borrower requests for
            review of licensing and engineering agreements in the early
            months of a project and the development of a more realistic
            project schedule. Lastly, it would have been prudent to
            utilize the technical capabilities of the Bank's
            Resident Mission to more frequently monitor project
            implementation and schedule changes.
